summary: The case involves an appeal against concurrent judgments of the High Court and Court of Appeal which convicted the appellant for conspiracy, robbery, and culpable homicide. The main issues were the propriety of allowing the prosecution to call additional witnesses after the defense had closed its case, and whether the circumstantial evidence presented was sufficient to sustain a conviction. The prosecution was initially forced to close its case prematurely but later obtained leave to call additional witnesses (PW3-PW7). These witnesses provided crucial evidence linking the appellant to the crime scene through items found there (shoes, cap, and stick) and footprints leading to his house. The appellant challenged both the procedural aspect of allowing additional witnesses and the quality of circumstantial evidence used to convict him. The Supreme Court upheld the lower courts' decisions, finding that the procedure was proper since the appellant's counsel did not oppose the application to call additional witnesses, and the circumstantial evidence presented formed an unbroken chain of circumstances that conclusively pointed to the appellant's guilt.
outcome: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal and affirmed both the conviction and sentence imposed by the trial court and upheld by the Court of Appeal.
ratios: A trial court has the power under section 237(1) of the Criminal Procedure Code to summon witnesses at any stage of proceedings provided doing so does not overreach any of the parties to the proceedings

Where circumstantial evidence is strong and gives rise to irresistible, cogent and compelling inference of guilt of the accused, leaving no room for any other rational conclusion, a conviction thereon may be sustained
A party who has an opportunity of being heard but failed to utilize it cannot be heard to complain of lack of fair hearing thereafter

Cases cannot be authorities for what they did not decide. A decided case furnishes a basis for the determination of a later case only if the facts or issues in the subsequent case are similar to those in the earlier case

precedents.context: The issue of jurisdiction is certainly a threshold one. It is either that a court has it and legitimately proceeds or in unlawfully proceeding, without the necessary jurisdiction, wastes not only the litigants but its own precious time. It is trite that proceedings of courts that lack jurisdiction, no matter how well same were conducted, are nullities. Jurisdiction remains the lifeline of all trials and that is why a challenge to the court's jurisdiction, in order to save time and costs, are raised even viva voce and for the first time in this court.
